did.head: Descriptive Summary

did.unittitle:
Letters of James Branch Cabell,
1922-1958
did.physdesc: This collection consists of 1 reel: positive; 35 mm.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p:
See the
University of Virginia Library’s use policy.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Letters of James Branch Cabell, Accession #5947-l, Special Collections Dept., University of Virginia Library, Charlottesville, Va.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: This collection was deposited on 1964 June 17.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Information
scopecontent.p: In this collection of letters, James Branch Cabell discusses his work, its publication and editions, especially The King Was in His Counting House;Hamlet Had an Uncle;and The First Gentlemen of America.Cabell also mentions Ellen Glasgow's literary interests and her health.

Recipients include Cabell's editors John Chipman Farrar, Stanley Rinehart, Adelaide Sherer, and Philip Wylie. Also included is a letter, ca. 1942, from Stephen Vincent Benét to Farrar complimenting and analysing Cabell's First Gentlemen of America.
These letters are on microfilm (M-1369), from originals in the Yale University Library. They are in the order in which they appear on the microfilm.
